mainmatter.p: A ringed space is a space equipped with a sheaf of rings, called the structure sheaf.
The locality requirement for a ringed space is to guarantee that the sections behave like functions valued in some field.

It is impossible in general to discuss the vanishing region of a section f \in \Gamma (U, \mathscr { O } )f∈Γ(U,O)f \in \Gamma (U, \mathscr { O } )f∈Γ(U,O). In algebraic geometry, such an overspill destroys most valuable information. We can talk about the maximal region on which the section is invertible, but this is different from being non-zero if sections don’t behave like functions. frontmatter.title: Stalks of locally ringed topological space

mainmatter.p: Given a ringed topological space, it is locally ringed iff every stalk is a local ring.

Recall the axiom for a local ring: if any sum is invertible, then one of the summand is invertible. When applied to the direct limit in each stalk, this immediately expands to the definition of a locally ringed space.

In particular, a crucial property is used in the reverse implication, i.e. if one open contains all the points of another, then the former covers the latter. This is equivalent to the condition of having enough points.
